info.title: Disputes
info.description:
Occasionally, something goes wrong with a customer's order. To dispute a charge, a customer can create a dispute with PayPal. PayPal merchants, partners, and external developers can use the PayPal Disputes API to manage customer disputes.
Note: In the live environment, merchants cannot create disputes but can only respond to customer-created disputes. However, merchants can create disputes in the sandbox environment.
A customer can also ask his or her bank or credit card company to dispute and reverse a charge, which is known as a chargeback. For more information, see Disputes, claims, chargebacks, and bank reversals.

When a customer disputes a charge, you can use this API to provide evidence that the charge is legitimate. To provide evidence or appeal a dispute, you submit a proof of delivery or proof of refund document or notes, which can include logs.

Normally, an agent at PayPal creates a dispute, updates the dispute status, and settles disputes, but now you can run test cases in the sandbox that complete these operations.

Important: The create, cancel, compute metrics, change reason, and validate eligibility methods are available as a limited-release solution at this time. For more information, reach out to your PayPal account manager.

For details, see Disputes Overview documentation.

post.description:
Important: This method is for sandbox use only.
Updates the status of a dispute, by ID, from UNDER_REVIEW to either:
  • WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE
  • WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE
This status change enables either the customer or merchant to submit evidence for the dispute. To make this call, the dispute status must be UNDER_REVIEW. Specify an action value in the JSON request body to indicate whether the status change enables the customer or merchant to submit evidence:
If action isThe status updates to
BUYER_EVIDENCE WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE
SELLER_EVIDENCE WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE

post.description:
Determines whether you can create a case for a transaction, by encrypted transaction ID. For an already created dispute, lists which reasons the customer can use to update a dispute, by ID.
Note: To call the determine dispute eligibility method in your sandbox, ask your PayPal account manager to add the required scopes.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that lists the eligible dispute reasons and ineligible dispute reasons.

get.description:
Lists disputes with a full or summary set of details. Default is a summary set of details, which shows the dispute_id, reason, status, dispute_amount, create_time, and update_time fields.

To filter the disputes in the response, specify one or more optional query parameters. To limit the number of disputes in the response, specify the page_size query parameter.

To list multiple disputes, set these query parameters in the request:
  • page_size=2
  • start_time instead of disputed_transaction_id

If the response contains more than two disputes, it lists two disputes and includes a HATEOAS link to the next page of results.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP 200 OK status code and a JSON response body that lists disputes with a full or summary set of details. Default is a summary set of details, which shows the dispute_id, reason, status, dispute_amount, create_time, and update_time fields for each dispute.

parameters.name: account_number
parameters.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a PayPal user account with this payer ID.
Note: By default, the list shows the disputes for the logged-in user who calls the API. The user invokes the API through an access token and the API fetches the disputes of the logged-in user based on this token. So, the user does not explicitly send his or her account number to the API. For partner accounts, shows details for all disputes that are related to merchants who are associated with the partner. For a MAM account, it can list disputes for a child account by account number.

parameters.name: start_time
parameters.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a creation date and time. The start time must be within the last 180 days. Value is in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

You can specify either but not both the `start_time` and `disputed_transaction_id` query parameters.

parameters.name: disputed_transaction_id
parameters.description:
Filters the disputes in the response by a transaction, by ID.

You can specify either but not both the `start_time` and `disputed_transaction_id` query parameter.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: The page number of the results, as a non-zero integer. Enables you to search by page number. Use in combination with the `page_size`.

parameters.name: page_size
parameters.description: Limits the number of disputes in the response to this value.

parameters.name: next_page_token
parameters.description: The token that describes the next page of results to fetch. The list disputes call returns this token in the HATEOAS links in the response.

parameters.name: total_required
parameters.description: Indicates whether to include the total number of items in the response.

parameters.name: fields
parameters.description: Filters the fields returned for each dispute in the response to a set of summary fields or all fields. Value is `summary` or `all`. The `all` value is supported for transaction ID queries but not supported for time-range queries. The set of summary fields are `dispute_id`, `reason`, `status`, `dispute_amount`, `create_time`, and `update_time`.

parameters.name: dispute_state
parameters.description: Filters the disputes in the response by a state. Separate multiple values with a comma (`,`). When you specify more than one dispute_state, the response lists disputes that belong to any of the specified dispute_state.

x-enum.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those with the REQUIRED_ACTION dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the REQUIRED_OTHER_PARTY_ACTION dispute state.

Filters the disputes in the response to those with the RESOLVED dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the OPEN_INQUIRIES dispute state.
Filters the disputes in the response to those with the APPEALABLE dispute state.

post.description:
Appeals a dispute, by ID. To appeal a dispute, use the appeal link in the HATEOAS links from the show dispute details response. If this link does not appear, you cannot appeal the dispute. Submit new evidence as a document or notes in the JSON request body. The following rules apply to document file types and sizes:
  • The merchant can upload up to 50 MB of files for a case.
  • Individual files must be smaller than 10 MB.
  • The supported file formats are JPG, GIF, PNG, and PDF.

To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the evidence in the JSON request body. For information about dispute reasons, see dispute reasons.

post.description:
Provides supporting information for a dispute, by ID. A merchant or buyer can make this request for disputes if they find the `provide-supporting-info` link in the HATEOAS links in the list disputes response. The party can provide the supporting information to PayPal to defend themselves only when the `dispute_life_cycle_stage` is `CHARGEBACK`, `PRE_ARBITRATION`, or `ARBITRATION`. They can provide a note that describes their part with details or upload any supporting documents to support their side. The following rules apply to document file types and sizes:
  • The party can upload up to 10 MB of files for a case.
  • Individual files must be smaller than 5 MB.
  • The supported file formats are JPG, GIF, PNG, and PDF.

To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the notes in the JSON request body. This method differs from the provide evidence method which supports only multipart request, where PayPal asks the concerned party for evidence.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

400.description: The request failed due to a validation error. The request returns the HTTP `400 Bad Request` status code.

404.description: The request failed due to the dispute is not available. The request returns the HTTP `404 Not Found` status code.

422.description: The requested action could not be completed. The request returns the HTTP `422 Unprocessable Entity` status code.

500.description: An internal server error occurred. The request returns the HTTP `500 Internal Server Error` status code.

parameters.name: dispute_id
parameters.description: The ID of the dispute for which to provide the supporting information.

parameters.name: supporting document
parameters.description: A file with evidence.

post.description:
Provides evidence for a dispute, by ID. A merchant can provide evidence for disputes with the WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE status while customers can provide evidence for disputes with the WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE status. Evidence can be a proof of delivery or proof of refund document or notes, which can include logs. A proof of delivery document includes a tracking number while a proof of refund document includes a refund ID. The following rules apply to document file types and sizes:
  • The merchant can upload up to 50 MB of files for a case.
  • Individual files must be smaller than 10 MB.
  • The supported file formats are JPG, GIF, PNG, and PDF.

To make this request, specify the dispute ID in the URI and specify the evidence in the JSON request body. For information about dispute reasons, see dispute reasons.

200.description: A successful request returns the HTTP `200 OK` status code and a JSON response body that includes a link to the dispute.

tags.name: disputes
tags.description: Use the `/disputes` resource to list disputes, create disputes, show dispute details, and partially a dispute. Normally, an agent at PayPal creates disputes but now you can run test cases in the sandbox that create disputes.

tags.name: disputes-actions
tags.description:
Use the `/disputes` resource with a dispute ID and an action to:
  • Accept a claim.
  • Accept an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Acknowledge the return of an item related to a dispute.
  • Settle a dispute.
  • Appeal a dispute.
  • Cancel a dispute.
  • Change the reason for a dispute.
  • Deny an offer to resolve dispute.
  • Escalate a dispute to a claim.
  • Make an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Make an offer to resolve a dispute.
  • Provide evidence for a dispute.
  • Provide supporting information for dispute.
  • In the sandbox, update the dispute status.
  • Send a message about a dispute to the other party in the dispute.

tags.name: referred-disputes
tags.description: Use the `/customer/referred-disputes` resource to create a dispute for a referred case that was created by a partner or marketplace, show details for a referred dispute, by ID, notify referred refunds completed to PayPal, notify PayPal about referred dispute adjudication updates, and determine the dispute eligibility for referred disputes.

tags.name: validate-eligibility
tags.description: Use the `/validate-eligibility/` resource to determine whether you can create a case for a transaction.

tags.name: compute-metrics
tags.description: Use the `/compute-metrics` resource to provide metrics for all disputes.

tags.name: validate-referred-dispute-eligibility
tags.description: Use the `/validate-referred-dispute-eligibility` resource to determine whether you can create a referred case for a transaction, by encrypted transaction ID.

tags.name: referred-disputes
tags.description: Use the `/referred-disputes` resource to create a dispute for a referred case that was created by a partner or marketplace, show details for a referred dispute, by ID, notify referred refunds completed to PayPal, notify PayPal about referred dispute adjudication updates, and determine the dispute eligibility for referred disputes.

tags.name: referred-disputes-actions
tags.description: Use the `/referred-disputes` resource with a dispute ID and an action to notify PayPal about adjudication updates for a referred dispute and notify PayPal about a refund for a referred dispute.

tags.name: partner-actions
tags.description: Use the `/disputes/{id}/partner-actions/` resource to show dispute action details and partially update a dispute action.

tags.name: search-suggestions
tags.description: Use the `/search-suggestions` resource to show search suggestions.

response-dispute_lifecycle_stage.json.description: The stage in the dispute lifecycle.

x-enum.description:
A customer and merchant interact in an attempt to resolve a dispute without escalation to PayPal. Occurs when the customer:
  • Has not received goods or a service.
  • Reports that the received goods or service are not as described.
  • Needs more details, such as a copy of the transaction or a receipt.

A customer or merchant escalates an inquiry to a claim, which authorizes PayPal to investigate the case and make a determination. Occurs only when the dispute channel is INTERNAL. This stage is a PayPal dispute lifecycle stage and not a credit card or debit card chargeback. All notes that the customer sends in this stage are visible to PayPal agents only. The customer must wait for PayPals response before the customer can take further action. In this stage, PayPal shares dispute details with the merchant, who can complete one of these actions:
  • Accept the claim.
  • Submit evidence to challenge the claim.
  • Make an offer to the customer to resolve the claim.

The first appeal stage for merchants. A merchant can appeal a chargeback if PayPal's decision is not in the merchant's favor. If the merchant does not appeal within the appeal period, PayPal considers the case resolved.

The second appeal stage for merchants. A merchant can appeal a dispute for a second time if the first appeal was denied. If the merchant does not appeal within the appeal period, the case returns to a resolved status in pre-arbitration stage.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Portable Postal Address (Medium-Grained)
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The portable international postal address. Maps to [AddressValidationMetadata](https://github.com/googlei18n/libaddressinput/wiki/AddressValidationMetadata) and HTML 5.1 [Autofilling form controls: the autocomplete attribute](https://www.w3.org/TR/html51/sec-forms.html#autofilling-form-controls-the-autocomplete-attribute).

address_line_1.description: The first line of the address. For example, number or street. For example, `173 Drury Lane`. Required for data entry and compliance and risk checks. Must contain the full address.

address_line_2.description: The second line of the address. For example, suite or apartment number.

address_line_3.description: The third line of the address, if needed. For example, a street complement for Brazil, direction text, such as `next to Walmart`, or a landmark in an Indian address.

admin_area_4.description:
The neighborhood, ward, or district. Smaller than `admin_area_level_3` or `sub_locality`. Value is:
  • The postal sorting code that is used in Guernsey and many French territories, such as French Guiana.
  • The fine-grained administrative levels in China.

admin_area_3.description:
A sub-locality, suburb, neighborhood, or district. Smaller than `admin_area_level_2`. Value is:
  • Brazil. Suburb, bairro, or neighborhood.
  • India. Sub-locality or district. Street name information is not always available but a sub-locality or district can be a very small area.

admin_area_2.description: A city, town, or village. Smaller than `admin_area_level_1`.

admin_area_1.description:
The highest level sub-division in a country, which is usually a province, state, or ISO-3166-2 subdivision. Format for postal delivery. For example, `CA` and not `California`. Value, by country, is:
  • UK. A county.
  • US. A state.
  • Canada. A province.
  • Japan. A prefecture.
  • Switzerland. A kanton.

postal_code.description: The postal code, which is the zip code or equivalent. Typically required for countries with a postal code or an equivalent. See [postal code](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Postal_code).

address_details.title: Address Details
address_details.description: The non-portable additional address details that are sometimes needed for compliance, risk, or other scenarios where fine-grain address information might be needed. Not portable with common third party and opensource. Redundant with core fields. For example, `address_portable.address_line_1` is usually a combination of `address_details.street_number` and `street_name` and `street_type`.

street_name.description: The street name. Just `Drury` in `Drury Lane`.

street_type.description: The street type. For example, avenue, boulevard, road, or expressway.

delivery_service.description: The delivery service. Post office box, bag number, or post office name.

building_name.description: A named locations that represents the premise. Usually a building name or number or collection of buildings with a common name or number. For example, Craven House.

sub_building.description: The first-order entity below a named building or location that represents the sub-premise. Usually a single building within a collection of buildings with a common name. Can be a flat, story, floor, room, or apartment.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description:
The [two-character ISO 3166-1 code](/docs/integration/direct/rest/country-codes/) that identifies the country or region.
Note: The country code for Great Britain is GB and not UK as used in the top-level domain names for that country. Use the `C2` country code for China worldwide for comparable uncontrolled price (CUP) method, bank card, and cross-border transactions.

Proof of refund issued to the buyer
Proof of delivery signature.

Copy of the police report filed.
More information has to be provided about the claim using the affidavit.

Check with buyer if item Delivered (seller provided Proof of Shipping)
Document confirming that the item has been confiscated.
Custom fees receipt paid by the buyer
Any resolution reached with the seller should be communicated to PayPal.
Any additional information of the item purchased.

More information required on how the item was damaged or was significantly different from the item advertised.
Any screenshot or download/usage log showing that the software or service was unavailable or non-functional.
Documentation from a third party or organization that evaluated this item that confirms they confiscated it.
Documentation supporting the claim that the item is damaged.

Report filed with a law enforcement agency or government organization. Examples of such agencies are -  Internet Crime Complaint Center (www.ic3.gov), state Consumer Protection office, state police or a Federal law enforcement agency such as the FBI or Postal Inspection Service.
Additional proof of shipment  such as a packing list, detailed invoice, or shipping manifest to confirm that all items have been shipped.
Documentation from the carrier should confirm the reason why they refuse to ship the item in question and the extent of the original damage.

Proof should be provided by an unbiased third-party, such as a dealer, appraiser or another individual or organisation that's qualified in the area of the item in question (other than yourself), and detail the extent of the damage or clearly explain how the item received significantly differs from the item advertised.

The document you have provided doesn't support your claim that the item is Significantly Not as Described. Please provide a document to clearly show how the item received significantly differs from the item advertised.
The document you have provided is illegible, unclear, or too dark to read.  Please provide a document that is legible and clear to read.
Online tracking information for remaining items that have to be shipped to the seller.
Confirmation that the item has been received.
In-store receipt or online verification should clearly show that the buyer picked up the item.
Tracking information should include the carrier name,  online tracking number and the website where the shipment can be tracked.
Proof of shipment or postage should be a copy of the actual shipping label on the package that shows the destination address and the carrier's stamp to verify the shipment date.
Online tracking information to confirm delivery of item.
Proof should be an in-store refund receipt or company documentation that clearly shows a completed refund for the transaction.
Proof should be compelling evidence to prove that the item or service was as described  and was delivered to the buyer.
Return address is required for the buyer to ship  the merchandise back to the seller.
To validate a claim,  a copy of the eparcel manifest showing the buyer's address from Australia Post is required.
The shipping manifest must show the buyer's address and can be obtained from the carrier.
Appeal affidavit is needed to make an appeal for any case outcome.
Check with buyer if the replacement of the item sent by the seller was received
Need Copy of Drivers license.
Additional Details about how account was accessed/what was changed.
Address where item was supposed to be delivered.
Confirmation that item was received and issue resolved.
Copy of merchant's response when the resolution was attempted.
A Detailed description about the account or card level permission given to another person.
Details of the merchandise's current location.
Details of where and when the card was lost/stolen?.
Details of the last valid transaction made on the card.
Other.

response-offer.json.title: Offer
response-offer.json.description: The merchant-proposed offer for a dispute.

buyer_requested_amount.description: The customer-requested refund for this dispute.

seller_offered_amount.description: The merchant-offered refund for this dispute.

history.description: An array of history information for an offer.

response-offer_type.json.title: Offer Type
response-offer_type.json.description: The merchant-proposed offer type for the dispute.

x-enum.description: The merchant must refund the customer without any item replacement or return. This offer type is valid in the chargeback phase and occurs when a merchant is willing to refund the dispute amount without any further action from customer. Omit the refund_amount and return_shipping_address parameters from the accept claim call.

The customer must return the item to the merchant and then merchant will refund the money. This offer type is valid in the chargeback phase and occurs when a merchant is willing to refund the dispute amount and requires the customer to return the item. Include the return_shipping_address parameter in but omit the refund_amount parameter from the accept claim call.

The merchant must do a refund and then send a replacement item to the customer. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase when a merchant is willing to refund a specific amount and send the replacement item. Include the offer_amount parameter in the make offer to resolve dispute call.

The merchant must send a replacement item to the customer with no additional refunds. This offer type is valid in the inquiry phase when a merchant is willing to replace the item without any refund. Omit the offer_amount parameter from the make offer to resolve dispute call.

offer_time.description: The date and time when the event occurred, in [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

x-enum.description: The actor is the customer.
The actor is the merchant.

event_type.description: The type of the history event.

x-enum.description: The merchant or customer proposed an offer.
The merchant or customer accepted the offer.
The merchant or customer rejected the offer.

gross_amount.description: The gross amount of the refund.

transaction_time.description: The date and time of the refund.

transaction_id.description: The ID of the transaction for the refund, as it appears to the merchant.

invoice_number.description: The ID of the invoice for the refund.

response-communication_details.json.title: Contact Details
response-communication_details.json.description: The contact details that a merchant provides to the customer to use to share their evidence documents.

email.description: The email address that is provided by the merchant where the customer can share the evidences.

note.description: The merchant provided notes that are visible to both the customer and PayPal.

time_posted.description: The date and time when the contact details were posted, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

response-partner_action.json.title: Partner Action
response-partner_action.json.description: A PayPal-requested or partner action for the dispute.

x-enum.description: The partner must provide the consumer with provisional credit.
The partner denies dispute and must reverse the provisional credit.
The partner accepts dispute and must provide permanent provisional credit to the consumer.
The partner must write off the dispute.

create_time.description: The date and time when the action was initiated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

update_time.description: The date and time when the action was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

due_time.description: The date and time before which the action must be performed, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

x-enum.description: The action is pending and awaits partner processing. For this type of action, the partner must update the action's status after they complete the required actions.
The partner has processed the action.

amount.description: The amount associated with the partner action, either it is recommended by PayPal for which the partner need to take action or it is taken by the partner at their end

response-supporting_info.json.title: Supporting Info
response-supporting_info.json.description: A merchant- or customer-submitted supporting information.

documents.description: An array of metadata for the documents which were uploaded as supporting information for the dispute.

x-enum.description: Information was submitted by the customer.
Information was submitted by the merchant.
Information was submitted by the partner.

provided_time.description: The date and time when the information was received, in [Internet date and time format](http://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

href.description: The complete target URL. To make the related call, combine the method with this [URI Template-formatted](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc6570) link. For pre-processing, include the `$`, `(`, and `)` characters. The `href` is the key HATEOAS component that links a completed call with a subsequent call.

rel.description: The [link relation type](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc5988#section-4), which serves as an ID for a link that unambiguously describes the semantics of the link. See [Link Relations](https://www.iana.org/assignments/link-relations/link-relations.xhtml).

method.description: The HTTP method required to make the related call.

mediaType.description: The media type, as defined by [RFC 2046](https://www.ietf.org/rfc/rfc2046.txt). Describes the link target.

encType.description: The media type in which to submit the request data.

schema.description: The schema that describes the request data.

targetSchema.description: The schema that describes the link target.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Link Schema
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The request data or link target.

items.title: Items
items.description: An item.

allOf.description: An array of sub-schemas. The data must validate against all sub-schemas.

items.title: All Of Item
items.description: A sub-schema against which the data must validate.

anyOf.description: An array of sub-schemas. The data must validate against one or more sub-schemas.

items.title: Any Of Item
items.description: A sub-schema against which the data must validate.

oneOf.description: An array of sub-schemas. The data must validate against one sub-schema.

items.title: One Of Item
items.description: A sub-schema against which the data must validate.

items.title: Link
items.description: A link.

media.title: Media
media.description: The media type and context-encoding scheme.

type.description: The media type. See [Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) Part Two: Media Types](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2046).

binaryEncoding.description: The content-encoding scheme. See [Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions (MIME) Part One: Format of Internet Message Bodies](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc2045).

pathStart.description: To apply this schema to the instances' URIs, start the URIs with this value.

name.description: The human-readable, unique name of the error.

message.description: The message that describes the error.

debug_id.description: The PayPal internal ID that is used for correlation purposes.

information_link.description: The information link, or URI, that shows detailed information about this error for the developer.

details.description: An array of additional details about the error.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Error Details
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The error details. Required for client-side `4XX` errors.

field.description: The field that caused the error. If the field is in the body, set this value to the JSON pointer to that field. Required for client-side errors.

value.description: The value of the field that caused the error.

location.description: The location of the field that caused the error. A valid value is `body`, `path`, or `query`. Default is `body`.

issue.description: The unique and fine-grained application-level error code.

description.description: The human-readable description for an issue. The description MAY change over the lifetime of an API, so clients **MUST NOT** depend on this value.

create_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was created, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

update_time.description: The date and time when the dispute was last updated, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

disputed_transactions.description: An array of transactions for which disputes were created.

disputed_account_activities.description: An array of merchant account activities.

dispute_amount.description: The amount in the transaction that the customer originally disputed. Because customers can sometimes dispute only part of the payment, the disputed amount might be different from the total gross or net amount of the original transaction.

dispute_fee.description: The fee in the disputed transaction.

fee_policy.description: Policy that determines whether the fee needs to be retained or returned while moving the money as part of dispute process.

external_reason_code.description: The code that identifies the reason for the credit card chargeback. Each card issuer follows their own standards for defining reason type, code, and its format. For more details about the external reason code, see the card issue site. Available for only unbranded transactions.

messages.description: An array of customer- or merchant-posted messages for the dispute.

buyer_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the customer must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the customer does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the merchant's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

seller_response_due_date.description: The date and time by when the merchant must respond to the dispute, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6). If the merchant does not respond by this date and time, the dispute is closed in the customer's favor. For example, *`yyyy`*-*`MM`*-*`dd`*`T`*`HH`*:*`mm`*:*`ss`*.*`SSS`*`Z`.

supporting_info.description: An array of all the supporting information that are associated to this dispute.

response-fee_policy.json.title: Fee Policy
response-fee_policy.json.description: Policy that determines whether the fee needs to be retained or returned while moving the money as part of dispute process.

x-enum.description: No fee needs to be retained.
All fees need to be retained.
Fixed fee associated to the transaction needs to be retained and all other fees need to be returned.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Patch Request
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: An array of JSON patch objects to apply partial updates to resources.

common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.title: Patch
common_components-v3-schema-json-openapi.description: The JSON patch object to apply partial updates to resources.

path.description: The JSON pointer to the target document location at which to complete the operation.

value.title: Patch Value
value.description: The value to apply. The `remove` operation does not require a value.

from.description: The JSON pointer to the target document location from which to move the value. Required for the `move` operation.

request-evidences.json.title: Provide Evidence Request
request-evidences.json.description: A merchant or customer request to provide evidence for a dispute.

evidences.description: An array of evidences for the dispute.

return_shipping_address.description:
The return address for the item.

Required when the customer must return an item to the merchant for the MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED dispute reason..

request-accept_claim.json.title: Accept Claim Request
request-accept_claim.json.description: A request by a merchant to accept a customer's merchandise claim.

note.description: The merchant's notes about the claim. PayPal can, but the customer cannot, view these notes.

accept_claim_reason.description: The merchant's reason for acceptance of the customer's claim.

x-enum.description: Merchant is accepting customer's claim as they could not ship the item back to the customer
Merchant is accepting customer's claim as it is taking too long for merchant to fulfil the order
Merchant is accepting customer's claim as the item is lost in mail or transit
Merchant is accepting customer's claim as the merchant is not able to find sufficient evidence to win this dispute
Merchant is accepting customers claims to follow their internal company policy
This is the default value merchant can use if none of the above reasons apply

invoice_id.description: The merchant-provided ID of the invoice for the refund. This optional value is used to map the refund to an invoice ID in the merchant's system.

return_shipping_address.description:
The return address for the item.

Required when the customer must return an item to the merchant for the MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED dispute reason, especially if the refund amount is less than the dispute amount.

refund_amount.description:
To accept a customer's claim, the amount that the merchant agrees to refund the customer. The subsequent action depends on the amount:
  • If this amount is less than the customer-requested amount, the dispute updates to require customer acceptance.
  • If this amount is equal to or greater than the customer-requested amount, this amount is automatically refunded to the customer and the dispute closes.

note.description: The note, if any, about why the merchant canceled the dispute.

transaction_ids.description: An array of encrypted transaction IDs for a canceled unauthorized dispute. If you omit this ID for unauthorized disputes, the issue is automatically canceled. Optional for other dispute types.

items.description: The encrypted transaction ID for a canceled unauthorized dispute. If you omit this ID for unauthorized disputes, the issue is automatically canceled. Optional for other dispute types.

cancellation_reason.description: The reason the merchant cancelled the item.

x-enum.description: The customer already received the item.
The customer already received a refund for the item.
The customer cancelled the dispute for another reason. If OTHER is specified, customer needs to specify more information in the notes field.
The customer received the provided shipping tracking information and agrees to cancel.
The customer received the item replacement and agrees to cancel.

request-change_reason.json.title: Change Reason Request
request-change_reason.json.description: A request to change the reason for a dispute.

disputed_account_activities.description: An array of customer-reported unauthorized account activities.

items.description: A customer-reported unauthorized account activity.

transaction_ids.description: An array of transaction IDs to add to the unauthorized issue.

items.description: The encrypted transaction ID.

buyer_requested_amount.description: The customer requested refund amount for this dispute. Applicable when the customer changes the dispute reason to MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED.

item_info.description: The customer purchased items in a disputed transaction.Applicable when the customer changes the dispute reason to MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED.

items.description: The information for a purchased item in a disputed transaction.

request-adjudicate.json.title: Settle Request
request-adjudicate.json.description: A request to settle a dispute in either the customer's or merchant's favor.

x-enum.description: Resolves the case in the customer's favor. Outcome is set to RESOLVED_BUYER_FAVOR.
Resolves the case in the merchant's favor. Outcome is set to RESOLVED_SELLER_FAVOR.

request-require_evidence.json.title: Require Evidence Request
request-require_evidence.json.description: Sandbox only. Updates the state of a dispute, by ID, to either WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE or WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE. This state change enables either the customer or merchant to submit evidence for the dispute. Specify an action value in the JSON request body to indicate whether the state change enables the customer or merchant to submit evidence.

action.description: The action. Indicates whether the state change enables the customer or merchant to submit evidence.

x-enum.description: Changes the status of the dispute to WAITING_FOR_BUYER_RESPONSE.
Changes the status of the dispute to WAITING_FOR_SELLER_RESPONSE.

request-escalate.json.title: Escalate Claim Request
request-escalate.json.description: A merchant request to escalate a dispute, by ID, to a PayPal claim.

note.description: The notes about the escalation of the dispute to a claim.

x-enum.description: The merchant indicates that shipment would have arrived by now.
The customer has evidence that the merchant might be fraudulent.
The customer already failed to reach a resolution with the merchant before filing this dispute.
The customer thinks he or she cannot reach a resolution with the merchant.
The customer didn't receive refund as mentioned by merchant.
The customer received lesser refund amount than expected.
Tracking id received from merchant is invalid.
The customer has other reasons, which are described in the comments. If OTHER is specified, customer needs to specify more information in the notes field.

buyer_requested_amount.description: The customer-requested refund amount for this dispute.

request-send_message.json.title: Send Message
request-send_message.json.description: The merchant request to send a message to the other party.

message.description: The message sent by the merchant to the other party.

request-make_offer.json.title: Make Offer Request
request-make_offer.json.description: A merchant request to make an offer to resolve a dispute.

note.description: The merchant's notes about the offer. PayPal can, but the customer cannot, view these notes.

offer_amount.description: The amount proposed to resolve the dispute.

return_shipping_address.description: The return address for the item. Required when the customer must return an item to the merchant for the MERCHANDISE_OR_SERVICE_NOT_AS_DESCRIBED dispute reason, especially if the refund amount is less than the dispute amount.

invoice_id.description: The merchant-provided ID of the invoice for the refund. This optional value maps the refund to an invoice ID in the merchant's system.

request-accept_offer.json.title: Accept Offer Request
request-accept_offer.json.description: A customer request to accept the offer made by the merchant.

note.description: The customer notes about accepting of offer. PayPal can but the merchant cannot view these notes.

request-deny_offer.json.title: Deny Offer Request
request-deny_offer.json.description: A customer request to deny the offer made by the merchant.

note.description: The customer notes about the denial of offer. PayPal can but the merchant cannot view these notes.

request-acknowledge_return_item.json.title: Acknowledge Return Item Request
request-acknowledge_return_item.json.description: A merchant request to acknowledge receipt of the disputed item that the customer returned.

note.description: The merchant provided notes. PayPal can but the consumer cannot view these notes.

request-provide_supporting_info.json.description: The provide supporting information request details.

notes.description: The notes that describe the defense.

response-dispute_eligibility.json.title: Dispute Eligibility Response
response-dispute_eligibility.json.description: The eligible and ineligible disputes with reasons.

seller_transaction_id.description: The seller transaction ID that is associated with the encrypted transaction ID that is passed in the request. The dispute creation is allowed on the buyer transaction ID, which must be passed in the create dispute call.

buyer_transaction_id.description: The buyer transaction ID that is associated with the `encrypted_transaction_id` passed in the request.

eligible_dispute_reasons.description: An array of the eligible disputes with reasons.

ineligible_dispute_reasons.description: An array of the ineligible disputes with ineligibility reasons.

allowable_life_cycle.title: Allowable Lifecycle
allowable_life_cycle.description: The details about the allowable lifecycle stage and the reason why it is allowed.

stage.description: The stage in the dispute life cycle where the dispute creation is allowed.

x-enum.description: Dispute is allowed in the INQUIRY lifecycle stage.
Dispute is allowed in the CHARGEBACK lifecycle stage.

reason.description: The reason why dispute creation is allowed in this lifecycle stage. Value is `SELLER_OPTED_OUT_OF_DISPUTE`, `LOCKED_SELLER`, `RESTRICTED_SELLER`, or `DISPUTE_DISABLED_PARTNER`.

response-ineligible_dispute_reason.json.title: Ineligible Dispute Reason
response-ineligible_dispute_reason.json.description: The ineligible dispute with the reason for ineligibility.

ineligibility_reason.description: The reason that the dispute cannot be created.

request-eligibility.json.title: Eligibility Request
request-eligibility.json.description: For a new case, lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons. For an existing dispute, lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons; the eligible reasons are the ones that the customer can use to update the dispute. To check the eligibility of case creation, specify the encrypted transaction ID. To check the eligibility of dispute reason modification, specify the dispute ID.

encrypted_transaction_id.description: The encrypted transaction ID. The response lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons.

dispute_id.description: The ID of the dispute. The response lists the eligible and ineligible dispute reasons. The customer can use the eligible reasons to update the dispute.

buyer_note.description: Customer provided description of the issue.

metrics.description: An array of dimension and measurement metrics for disputes.

key.description: The group name for a dimension.

count.description: The count of items in a group.

amount.description: An array of the sums of amounts for each currency.

items.description: The sum of amounts for each currency.

dimension.description: The dimension for which to list metrics.

x-enum.description: Shows the results of metrics by the STATUS dimension. For example, if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different status.
Shows the results of metrics by the REASON dimension. For example if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different reason.
Shows the results of metrics by the OUTCOME dimension. For example if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different outcome.
Shows the results of metrics by the DISPUTE_STATE dimension. For example if the measure is COUNT, shows the count of disputes by different dispute states.

measure.description: The measure for the dimension for which to list metrics.

x-enum.description: Shows the count of disputes by the dimension in the request.
Shows the sum of dispute amount of the disputes by the dimension in the request.
Shows the sum of transaction amount of associated disputes by the dimension in the request.
Shows the sum of refund amount of associated disputes by the dimension in the request.

request-filter.json.title: Filter
request-filter.json.description: A set of filters that you can use to filter the disputes in the response.

email.description: Filters the disputes in the response by an email.

name.description: Filters the disputes in the response by the full name of a counter party.

reasons.description: Filters the disputes in the response by one or more reasons. Use a comma to separate multiple reasons. The response lists disputes that belong to any of the specified reasons.

statuses.description: Filters the disputes in the response by one or more statuses. Use a comma to separate multiple statuses. The response lists disputes with any of the specified statuses.

create_time_before.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were created before this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

create_time_after.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were created after this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

update_time_before.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were updated before this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

update_time_after.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that were updated after this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

response_due_date_before.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that are due before this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

response_due_date_after.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that are due after this date and time, in [Internet date and time format](https://tools.ietf.org/html/rfc3339#section-5.6).

dispute_amount_gte.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that have a dispute amount that is greater than or equal to this amount.

dispute_amount_lte.description: Filters the disputes in the response to those that have a dispute amount that is less than or equal to this amount.

corrected_search_text.description: The possible DidYouMean value if there are no suggestions for given search_text.

Occurs when a customer has not received goods or a service, the goods or service are not as described, or the customer needs additional details on a transaction, such as a copy of the transaction or a receipt

This stage occurs when a customer or merchant escalates an inquiry to a claim. Claims give PayPal the authority to investigate the case and determine an outcome if the dispute channel is `INTERNAL`. This state is a PayPal dispute lifecycle stage and is not to be interpreted as a credit card or debit card charge back
